summary: This document is a New York Times article reporting on a lawsuit filed by the Virgin Islands Attorney General against Jeffrey Epstein's estate. The lawsuit alleges Epstein sexually abused and trafficked hundreds of young women and girls on his private Caribbean islands, with activity continuing as recently as 2018. It seeks forfeiture of his islands and dissolution of shell companies used in the trafficking scheme.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Wealthy financier accused of running a decades-long sex trafficking scheme from his private islands in the Virgin Islands. He died by suicide in jail in August 2019 while awaiting trial.

persons.name: Denise N. George
persons.role: Attorney General of the Virgin Islands
persons.context: Filed the lawsuit against Epstein's estate, alleging expanded scope of trafficking activities in the Caribbean through 2018. She is leading the government's case to seize Epstein's assets.

persons.name: Darren K. Indyke
persons.context: Epstein's executor who is managing his estate and proposed a victim compensation fund with confidentiality requirements, which the lawsuit opposes.

persons.name: Ali Watkins
persons.context: New York Times reporter who wrote the article summarizing the lawsuit and its allegations.

persons.name: Bridgette Carr
persons.role: Director of Human Trafficking Clinic at University of Michigan Law School
persons.context: Consulted with the Virgin Islands Attorney General's team on the case and commented on the legal complexities of human trafficking cases.

connections.description: George is suing Epstein's estate on behalf of the Virgin Islands government, seeking forfeiture of his assets for alleged sex trafficking crimes.
Indyke is the executor of Epstein's estate, responsible for managing his assets and proposed a victim compensation fund.
George's lawsuit opposes Indyke's proposal for a confidential victim compensation fund, arguing it conceals criminal activities.
Carr consulted with George's legal team on the human trafficking case against Epstein's estate.

events.title: Virgin Islands lawsuit filed
events.description: Attorney General Denise N. George files lawsuit against Jeffrey Epstein's estate alleging sex trafficking on Caribbean islands through 2018.

events.title: Epstein's death in jail
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein hanged himself at the Metropolitan Correctional Center in Manhattan while awaiting trial on federal sex trafficking charges.

events.title: Epstein charged by Manhattan prosecutors
events.description: Federal prosecutors in Manhattan charged Epstein with sexually exploiting dozens of women and girls in New York and Florida.

events.title: Epstein refused investigator access
events.description: Epstein refused to permit a Virgin Islands Department of Justice investigator to enter Little Saint James, claiming the dock was his 'front door'.

events.title: Recent trafficking observed
events.description: Air traffic controllers observed Epstein leaving his private plane with girls who looked as young as 11 years old.

events.title: Epstein's Florida conviction
events.description: Epstein was convicted in Florida for solicitation of prostitution, after which his lawyers claimed he had been law-abiding.

keyFacts: The lawsuit alleges Epstein trafficked and abused hundreds of young women and girls on his private Caribbean islands, with activity continuing as recently as 2018.
Epstein maintained a computerized database to track the availability and movements of women and girls, some as young as 11-12 years old.
The Virgin Islands Attorney General seeks forfeiture of Epstein's two private islands (Little Saint James and Great Saint James) and dissolution of shell companies used in the trafficking enterprise.
Epstein's estate is valued at approximately $500 million, and there are competing proposals for how to allocate these assets to victims.
The lawsuit opposes the estate executor's proposal for a confidential victim compensation fund, arguing it would conceal criminal activities.
